text: A Pensacola man is in the Santa Rosa County Jail after a death in Escambia County.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The Sheriff's Office arrested Timothy Kramer after finding his wife dead from a gunshot wound.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: 47-year-old Rosa Kramer was reported missing yesterday.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Deputies found her dead at a home on Hillcrest Avenue around midnight.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: They also found a dog with a gunshot wound and took it to a vet where it later died.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Kramer was arrested by Milton Police this morning.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: He's charged with homicide and animal cruelty.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: With a busy election season less than a month away, Escambia County is making sure all of its voting machines are up to par ahead of the primaries.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We got a behind-the-scenes look at how it all works.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: It's called the logic and accuracy test.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: This is where we test the equipment that will be deployed for the election, making sure that it all works properly, but really to make sure that a vote for Robert gets counted as a vote for Robert.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: Going through all of the various potential scenarios that could happen on election day, like if a ballot is duplicated or spoiled.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We run all the actual ballots that we'll be using on election day, and again, make sure that those votes are counted accurately.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: This is a vote-by-mail ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: We know it's a vote-by-mail ballot because it has the V up at the top of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: So this machine should reject that ballot because it was intended for vote-by-mail.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: Ballots can go in head first, feet first, face up, face down, any way but sideways.
speaker: SPEAKER_21

text: They even have ADA accessible machines for people who may be blind or deaf.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Bender says there are 80 precincts in Escambia County and 72 polling locations.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We'll be polling about 86 of the tabulators during this primary election.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: And so we've gone and tested a percentage of those.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: He says he's expecting a lot of foot traffic to the polls.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: We expect a high turnout for the general.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: We're probably going to look at about 35, 40 percent for the primary.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: We did have our books closing, so the last day for people to register or change their party has already passed.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: They can still request a vote by mail ballots.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: We've had about 26,000 ballots go out already.
speaker: SPEAKER_11

text: He says the deadline is August 8th to request a vote by mail ballot.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Since the last presidential election, there has been some distrust about if votes were counted accurately.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Here are the steps the county makes sure that they are tonight at 5 o'clock.

text: The Navarre Chamber is hosting a candidate forum for Santa Rosa County seats.

text: It starts at 5.30 tonight at East Bay K-8 School on Elkhart Drive.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The Florida Department of Education is releasing report cards for schools and school districts.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Escambia County Public Schools earned a B. Santa Rosa and Okaloosa County school districts both got an A.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Looking at the breakdown for individual schools county by county, these numbers include charter schools, some of which are not overseen by their local school district.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Half of Escambia County schools earned a C. The only D was for Warrington Prep, formerly known as Warrington Middle, which is not part of the school district.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Most Santa Rosa County schools earned A's and B's.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Baghdad Elementary and Coastal Connections Academy earned the only D's.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: Okaloosa County schools earned mostly A's and B's.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: No D's here, but Destin High, Emerald Coast Career Institute, and Richburg School were given incompletes.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: And joining us now, the superintendent of Escambia County Public Schools, Keith Leonard.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Welcome and congratulations.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Thank you for having me.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: There's some very big news coming out of Escambia County.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: We have no DNF schools.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: And last year, we had nine.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Correct.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: To what do you attribute this incredible success?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Hard work and commitment by 37,000 plus students, 2,700 plus students, and all the employees of the Escambia County School District.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Pulling hard, working all in the same direction, and caring about one another.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Really, really excited about these results.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But to see that kind of a turnaround in a year's time, there seems like there would have been something or some things that you could attribute that to.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So, you know, we really began to focus on the learning model that we have in Escambia County, whether it be pacing guides, subject area coursework, making certain that all the teachers in all of our schools are in the same place at the same time, teaching very rigorous subject area matter.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then, you know, from one year ago when you and I met and started talking about what we were going to do in Escambia County Public Schools, we've been focusing in on attendance, behavior, and stability.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Those students in our school district know we love and care about them.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They know we're going to give them the resources and the things that they need to be successful.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We set very high expectations for our students.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: When you do something like that, when you start making those kinds of changes, it would seem that you need to have buy in from everybody.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You started out initially talking about the students.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: You started talking about the educators, the teachers that you got them on board.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What about getting the parents on board?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Obviously, you had to have some connection to the homes.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Yes, ma'am.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You know, that's right.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We talked about SEC, students, employees, and community.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we have seen tremendous buy-in from our community, whether it be right here at WAR, Navy Federal, just a multitude of community partners stepping up.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: A couple of weeks ago, I had the opportunity to visit out of the Pensacola Naval Air Station.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They are our partners in public education here in Escambia County.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I'm starting to see that with our community members.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: They all realize that we're going to be pulling in the same direction.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We need their help, and they are stepping up to do so.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Now, that is one of the criticisms, and let's talk about that, that we have heard from the military community when it comes to Escambia County, that they needed to see improvements and changes in the educational system here.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Yes, ma'am.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: That this was a failing so far as they saw and something that had to change.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Yes, ma'am.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And I think these results will show that at least for one year, they did change in a very positive direction.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The tough part is for 24-25, that sustainability.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: But I believe we have tough, committed individuals, whether it be the students or our employees, that are going to make sure they continue to strive for that success.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: All right, you talked about sustainability.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Yes, ma'am.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What needs to happen from here to get those grades, one, even higher?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Correct.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Or certainly to sustain those.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Where do you see areas of improvement?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What are you looking at August 12th, a new school year?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: Right.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: What things are you implementing going forward?
speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: So we need to make certain we continue to work on reading proficiency.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Last year we saw, I think it was right out of 48 or 49 percent of our students that entered kindergarten were ready to read.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: As you know, we've partnered with Building Brains at the Studer Community Institute.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I believe we'll begin to see that number rise.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Our families start realizing that the better prepared a child is when they get to kindergarten, it's going to help them be successful in early grades, more importantly in school, and then certainly in life.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Reading proficiency, math proficiency, I think I shared with Brent here just a little while ago, about 90% of our students at Molino Park Elementary School...
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We're proficient in math.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: It was like 91% at NB Cook.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Those are two different communities, yet you see a really good success rate as it relates to proficiency.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: We had one school that moved from a D to an A. Being able to sustain that is going to be critical so that the perception in our community is that we are your schools of choice and that our community will continue to pull for this Canby County school system.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: All right.
speaker: SPEAKER_01

speaker: SPEAKER_01

text: A new multi-use path is now open on Perdido Key.

text: Escambia County leaders cut the ribbon yesterday.

text: It's already being used by residents and visitors.
speaker: SPEAKER_04

text: The path is just over four miles long, stretching from River Road to the western boundary of Perdido Key State Park.

text: It's that time of year again, hurricane season.

text: News Radio 92.3 provides informative, local, and dependable coverage to make sure you're informed of any major storms coming to our area.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Before a storm, we keep you informed of the storm's track, where food and gas shortages occur, and where you can get sandbags.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: During the storm, we stay on the air to let you know where the storm is headed, where power outages occur, road closures, and other storm warnings.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Then after the storm, we get you the information to help you recover from the storm.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: News Radio 92.3, informative, local, dependable, hurricane headquarters.
